column4: Hi not sure where to ask this question ... but i have a dedicated server with Ubuntu ... i would like to access its /var/www via its ip ... i have installed it phpmyadmin on it via ssh and can access phpmyadmin login but nothing else ... how do i access its /var/www via its ip ?
what is the error you get
the error is "Not Found" the requested / is not found on this server
in your DocumentRoot, there is no index file (e.g. index.html or index.php), so if you just type http://<ipaddress> it returns that error
do you have a subdir in /var/www ? Some application
i have just an index file in /var/www and there is a folder with another test index.html too
and http://<ip>/index.html (explicitly) also returns the same error?
see what /var/log/apach2/error_log says
[Thu Feb 19 14:28:20 2009] [error] [client *IP*] File does not exist: /htdocs
it seems that your DocRoot is not correctly configured
go check the settings in /etc/apache2/sites-enabled
apache expects the root to be at /htdocs, not /var/www
restarting apache2 gives this warning too "[warn] NameVirtualHost *:80 has no VirtualHosts" and ... waiting apache2: apr_sockaddr_info_get() failed for localhost.localdomai
well it seems the apache config is a little off...
site-enable folder is empty
see in /etc/apache2/sites-available/ if there is a file called "default"
that file is in site-enabled
site-enabled folder was *empty* you said. site-available has default file?
if the site-enabled folder is empty enable, the "default" virtual host by using command "/usr/sbin/a2ensite default"
that will make a symlink from the default file in sites-available to a 000-default in sites-enabled.
from the main apache2.conf this site-enabled directory is included in the config. So if the link exists, edit the default file to suit your needs, like editing the DocumentRoot
yay! :)

well, the thing about no virtualhosts should be gone by now. As far as the other one concerns, I'd like to setup my webserver to know the hosts ServerName, and add that ip to the /etc/hosts file, that way apache know what it's talking about... or who :-)
cheers.
